1.text: Lo, mine eye hath seen all this, Mine ear hath heard and understood it.

2.text: What ye know, the same do I know also: I am not inferior unto you.

3.text: Surely I would speak to the Almighty, And I desire to reason with God.

4.text: But ye are forgers of lies; Ye are all physicians of no value.

5.text: Oh that ye would altogether hold your peace! And it would be your wisdom.

6.text: Hear now my reasoning, And hearken to the pleadings of my lips.

7.text: Will ye speak unrighteously for God, And talk deceitfully for him?

8.text: Will ye show partiality to him? Will ye contend for God?

9.text: Is it good that he should search you out? Or as one deceiveth a man, will ye deceive him?

10.text: He will surely reprove you, If ye do secretly show partiality.

11.text: Shall not his majesty make you afraid, And his dread fall upon you?

12.text: Your memorable sayings are proverbs of ashes, Your defences are defences of clay.

13.text: Hold your peace, let me alone, that I may speak; And let come on me what will.

14.text: Wherefore should I take my flesh in my teeth, And put my life in my hand?

15.text: Behold, he will slay me; I have no hope: Nevertheless I will maintain my ways before him.

16.text: This also shall be my salvation, That a godless man shall not come before him.

17.text: Hear diligently my speech, And let my declaration be in your ears.

18.text: Behold now, I have set my cause in order; I know that I am righteous.

19.text: Who is he that will contend with me? For then would I hold my peace and give up the ghost.

20.text: Only do not two things unto me; Then will I not hide myself from thy face:

21.text: Withdraw thy hand far from me; And let not thy terror make me afraid.

22.text: Then call thou, and I will answer; Or let me speak, and answer thou me.

23.text: How many are mine iniquities and sins? Make me to know my transgression and my sin.

24.text: Wherefore hidest thou thy face, And holdest me for thine enemy?

25.text: Wilt thou harass a driven leaf? And wilt thou pursue the dry stubble?

26.text: For thou writest bitter things against me, And makest me to inherit the iniquities of my youth:

27.text: Thou puttest my feet also in the stocks, And markest all my paths; Thou settest a bound to the soles of my feet:

28.text: Though I am like a rotten thing that consumeth, Like a garment that is moth-eaten.
